channel.title: Java Lesson's [Question]
channel.description:
Hello Moparscape, Where Would U Recommend Me Doing Free Online Java Classes Like Code-academy, Ive finished that and it really didn't teach me anything :l
Post Ones That Cost To, Ill Be Doing Those In Like 1 Month.

item.title: Java Lesson's [Question]
item.dc:creator: @doom_j doom_j
item.description:
@doom_j wrote:

Excepting to know how to program without understand the concepts involved with that language is stupid, by understanding the language you will be able to program easier and will make less mistakes. You must first take baby steps, then you walk, and once you have mastered that start to run.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Lesson's [Question]
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

Reading won’t do you any good unless your actually programming something. Doing simple tasks such as delayed actions, input/output, statements, returns etc, all have their advantages in real time coding which really all you need to find out if when to apply the knowledge.

I’m sure you must know the basics of coding (if statements, arrays etc) if so making simple calculators should be easy.
All I can say is screw your “lessons” and do some application development of your own or work on something as it’ll all soak in your head eventually. This is exactly what they would make you do in school. Learn, code, develop.

Read full topic

item.title: Java Lesson's [Question]

item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

http://docs.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/getStarted/

granted the site has a changed a lot since I remember :o

item.title: Java Lesson's [Question]
item.dc:creator: @zzjimmy zzjimmy
item.description:
@zzjimmy wrote:

Are you only looking for web sites, or do ebooks work as well? I know a very good site where you can get digital copies of excellent Java books that sell for over $100 on paper. Books work much better than sites, unless you’re looking for something specific.

Read full topic
